dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Returnly just secured a 20 million dollar Series B funding round, led by Craft Ventures and backed by PayPal cofounder Max Levchin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Returnly just secured a twenty million dollar Series B funding round, led by Craft Ventures and backed by PayPal cofounder Max Levchin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge vote of confidence, especially for a company tackling one of e-commerce's biggest pain points—delayed refunds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge vote of confidence, especially for a company tackling one of e-commerce's biggest pain points-delayed refunds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They're offering instant store credit to 85% of customers before the item is even shipped back, which is pretty bold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They're offering instant store credit to eighty five percent of customers before the item is even shipped back, which is pretty bold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're working with retailers like Rothys and Fanatics, right? That's thousands of merchants already on board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're working with retailers like Rothys and Fanatics, right? That's thousands of merchants already on board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company, which works with thousands of retailers like Rothys, Untuckit and Fanatics, was launched in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they've processed nearly 210 million dollars in returns over the past three years. They take a cut on each transaction, plus subscription fees from merchants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they've processed nearly two hundred ten million dollars in returns over the past three years. They take a cut on each transaction, plus subscription fees from merchants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how they use data from their network to assess shopper risk—like, they look at your shopping history across all their partner stores.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how they use data from their network to assess shopper risk-like, they look at your shopping history across all their partner stores.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This essentially means it analyzes a consumers past shopping activity at the retailers that it works with to make a decision.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they assume the risk if an item isn't returned, which is kind of a gamble. But their founder, Eduardo Vilar, says their whole model relies on that network effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they assume the risk if an item isn't returned, which is kind of a gamble. But their founder, Eduardo Vilar, says their whole model relies on that network effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly then assumes the risk that a product is never returned, whether thats because a customer fails to ship it back in the first place, it arrives damaged or it gets lost in the mail. Our whole business model is predicated on the network effect, says Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it seems to be working—nine out of ten customers order something else before even sending the first return back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it seems to be working-nine out of ten customers order something else before even sending the first return back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, they end up spending 24% more than their original order value. It's like… instant gratification keeps people shopping.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, they end up spending twenty four percent more than their original order value. It's like... instant gratification keeps people shopping.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theyre likely to outspend the original size of their order, too, by 23%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is exactly what Jeff Fluhr from Craft Ventures pointed out—retailers get a revenue boost, shoppers get that immediate satisfaction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is exactly what Jeff Fluhr from Craft Ventures pointed out-retailers get a revenue boost, shoppers get that immediate satisfaction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adds Jeff Fluhr, a partner at Craft Ventures and the founder of StubHub: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And with online returns hitting over 102 billion dollars in 2017 alone, there's clearly a massive opportunity here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with online returns hitting over one hundred two billion dollars in twenty seventeen alone, there's clearly a massive opportunity here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, over $100 billion of items that were purchased online were returned, according to the U.S. Postal Services Office of Inspector General.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Though I wonder, like, what happens when things just never get returned? They didn't share numbers on that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Though I wonder, like, what happens when things just never get returned? They didn't share numbers on that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company declined to disclose any figures surrounding how many items are never returned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Vilar mentioned they might nudge customers with emails or simplify returns with pre-printed labels, but it sounds like their recourse is pretty limited.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Vilar mentioned they might nudge customers with emails or simplify returns with pre-printed labels, but it sounds like their recourse is pretty limited.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, in the age of Affirm and Klarna financing everything, Returnly's approach feels like a natural next step for smoothing out e-commerce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, in the age of Affirm and Klarna financing everything, Returnly's approach feels like a natural next step for smoothing out e-commerce.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's all about reducing friction so people just… keep spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's all about reducing friction so people just... keep spending.
